title: Abukar Ali Adan
about: Adan is the deputy leader of al-Shabaab. He spent several years as al-Shabaab’s military chief after previously heading the Jabhat, al-Shabaab’s military wing.

title: Andrey Stanislavovich Korinets
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Hamas’s Financial Network
associated_organization: Hamas;  Harakat al-Muqawama al-Islamiya;   Izz al-Din al-Qassam Battalions;  Izz al-Din al-Qassam Brigades;  Izz al-Din al-Qassam Forces;  Izz al-Din al-Qassim Battalions;  Izz al-Din al-Qassim Brigades;  Izz al-Din al-Qassim Forces;  Students of Ayyash;  Students of the Engineer;  Yahya Ayyash Units;  Al Rowad Real Estate Development;  Al Zawaya Group for Development and Investment Sociedad Limitada;   Larrycomm for Investment Ltd.;  Trend GYO;  Zawaya Group for Development and Investment Co.
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the disruption of financial mechanisms of the terrorist organization Hamas, also known as Harakat al-Muqawama al-Islamiya.

title: Ruslan Aleksandrovich Peretyatko
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Attack on DusitD2 Hotel Complex, Nairobi, Kenya
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information on Mohamoud Abdi Aden and any other individual responsible for the 2019 attack by al-Shabaab terrorists on the DusitD2 Hotel complex in Nairobi, Kenya. On the afternoon of January 15, 2019, al-Shabaab gunmen armed with explosives, automatic weapons, and grenades attacked the DusitD2 commercial center, a 6-building complex of shops, offices, and a hotel. At least 21 people, including one U.S. citizen, were killed in the assault. Al-Shabaab —an affiliate of the al-Qa’ida terrorist organization —released live updates throughout the attack via its official Shahada News Agency and issued a press release in which it stated that the attack was in response to guidance from then al-Qa’ida leader Ayman Zawahiri.

title: Murder of Shakeel Khan (Johnson City, New York | March 30, 2019)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information leading to the arrest or conviction in any country of any individual who committed, attempted or conspired to commit, or aided or abetted in the commission of the murder of Shakeel Khan.

title: Attack on Asasey Hotel
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information any individual responsible for the 2019 attack on the Asasey Hotel in Kismayo, Somalia.

title: Abdullahi Osman Mohamed
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on Abdullahi Osman Mohamed.

title: Attack on Manda Bay Airfield, Kenya
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information on Maalim Ayman and any other individual responsible for the January 5, 2020, terrorist attack on Manda Bay Airfield, Kenya. The Manda Bay facility is a Kenya Defense Forces military base utilized by U.S. armed forces to provide training and counterterrorism support to East African partners, respond to crises, and protect U.S. interests in the region.

title: Abu Ali al-Tunisi
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information leading to the identification or location of Abu Ali al-Tunisi. Al-Tunisi is a key leader of the Islamic State of Iraq and ash-Sham (ISIS), a terrorist organization that continues to pose a threat to the United States and its interests abroad.

title: Al-Shabaab’s Financial Network
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the disruption of the financial mechanisms of the terrorist organization al-Shabaab. Al-Shabaab’s financial operations and facilitation networks help sustain its operations and fund its terrorist attacks that have resulted in thousands of deaths of innocent civilians and security forces in Somalia and neighboring countries.

title: Maalim Ayman
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information on Maalim Ayman, leader of Jaysh Ayman, an al-Shabaab unit that has conducted terrorist attacks in Kenya and Somalia. On January 5, 2020, al-Shabaab terrorists attacked Kenyan and U.S. personnel at Manda Bay Airfield, Kenya, killing two U.S. contractor pilots and a U.S. Army specialist acting as an air traffic controller. A third U.S. contractor and two other U.S. service members were injured in the attack.

title: Emennet Pasargad
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any foreign person, including a foreign entity, who knowingly engaged or is engaging in interference in U.S. elections, as well as information leading to the prevention, frustration, or favorable resolution of an act of foreign election interference.

title: ISIS’s Financial Network
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the disruption of the financial mechanisms of the terrorist group Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS). ISIS relies on financing and facilitation networks to sustain operations and launch attacks in Syria and the surrounding region.

title: Foreign Interference in US Elections
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information on foreign interference in U.S. elections.

title: Yevgeniy Viktorovich Prigozhin &Associates
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any foreign person, including a foreign entity, who knowingly engaged or is engaging in interference in U.S. elections, as well as information leading to the prevention, frustration, or favorable resolution of an act of foreign election interference.

title: Conti
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Petr Nikolayevich Pliskin
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Yuriy Sergeyevich Andrienko
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Foreign Malicious Cyber Activity Against U.S. Critical Infrastructure
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Sergey Vladimirovich Detistov
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Marat Valeryevich Tyukov
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Pavel Valeryevich Frolov
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Artem Valeryevich Ochichenko
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Anatoliy Sergeyevich Kovalev
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Evgeny Viktorovich Gladkikh
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Mikhail Mikhailovich Gavrilov
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Pavel Aleksandrovich Akulov
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of any person who, while acting at the direction or under the control of a foreign government, participates in malicious cyber activities against U.S. critical infrastructure in violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA).

title: Terrorist Attack Against Americans in Bangladesh
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the killing of Avijit Roy and the concurrent attack on Rafida Bonya Ahmed in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

title: Attack at Kabul’s International Airport
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information on those responsible for the August 26, 2021 terrorist attack at the international airport in Kabul, Afghanistan. A suicide bomber attacked the airport as the United States and other governments undertook large-scale evacuation efforts of their citizens and vulnerable Afghans. At least 185 people were killed in the attack, including 13 U.S. service members supporting evacuation operations. More than 150 people, including 18 U.S. service members, were injured. ISIS-K, a U.S.-designated Foreign Terrorist Organization, claimed responsibility for the attack.

title: Kidnapping of Ihsan Ashour (Baghdad | December 13, 2019)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information leading to those responsible for the December 13, 2019 abduction of U.S. citizen Ihsan Ashour in Baghdad.

title: Kidnapping of Cydney Mizell (Kandahar City, Afghanistan | 2008)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information leading to the location, recovery, and return of Cydney Mizell.

title: Issa Barrey
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on Issa Barrey for his participation in the 2017 Tongo Tongo, Niger attack. Issa Barrey is believed to be a key ISIS-Greater Sahara (ISIS-GS) lieutenant.

title: Issa Jimaraou
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on Issa Jimaraou for his participation in the 2017 Tongo Tongo, Niger attack. Issa Jimaraou is a member of ISIS-Greater Sahara (ISIS-GS) and believed to be subordinate to ISIS-GS lieutenants Ousmane Illiassou Djibo, also known as Petit Chapori, and Issa Barrey.

title: Abu Huzeifa
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on Abu Huzeifa, also known as Higgo, for his participation in the 2017 Tongo Tongo, Niger attack. Abu Huzeifa is an ISIS-Greater Sahara (ISIS-GS) commander.

title: Ibrahim Ousmane
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on Ibrahim Ousmane, also known as Dandou Cheffou, for his participation in the 2017 Tongo Tongo, Niger attack. Ibrahim Ousmane is an ISIS-Greater Sahara (ISIS-GS) commander.

title: ISIS Kidnapping Networks –Clerics (Syria | February-July 2013)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on ISIS kidnapping networks or for information leading to the location, recovery, and return of Maher Mahfouz, Michael Kayyal, Gregorios Ibrahim, Bolous Yazigi, and Paolo Dall’Oglio.

title: Hizballah’s Financial Network
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the disruption of the financial mechanisms of Hizballah. Hizballah relies on financing and facilitation networks to sustain operations and launch attacks globally. Hizballah earns almost one billion dollars annually through direct financial support from Iran, international businesses and investments, donor networks, corruption, and money laundering activities.

title: Kidnapping and Murder of William Buckley (Beirut, Lebanon | March 16, 1984)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the kidnapping and murder of William Buckley. Buckley was the CIA station chief in Lebanon, a role for which he volunteered after the 1983 U.S. Embassy Beirut bombing that killed 63 people, including 17 Americans. On March 16, 1984, Buckley was kidnapped in Beirut on his way to work. He was interrogated and tortured before he died in captivity on June 3, 1985. Buckley was among the 100 victims, mostly Westerners, whom Hizballah and Hizballah-linked terrorists kidnapped and held hostage during the decade-long Lebanon hostage crisis.

title: Assault on Tourists (Bwindi Park, Uganda | March 1, 1999)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the 1999 assault on tourists in Bwindi Park, Uganda.

title: Union Texas Petroleum Murders (Karachi, Pakistan | November 12, 1997)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the Union Texas Petroleum (UTP) murders. On November 12, 1997, four UTP employees were on their way to work in Karachi, Pakistan. As their station wagon crossed a bridge leading to the UTP office building, two gunmen jumped out of a red Honda Civic and fired into the car. All four U.S. employees, as well as their Pakistani driver, were killed in the attack.

title: Kidnapping and Murder of U.S. Marine Corps Colonel William Higgins (Lebanon | February 17, 1988)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the kidnapping and murder of U.S. Marine Corps Colonel William Higgins. Higgins was part of a United Nations peacekeeping mission in southern Lebanon when he was kidnapped on February 17, 1988. His captors tortured and interrogated Higgins before killing him. Higgins was among the 100 victims, mostly Westerners, whom Hizballah and Hizballah-linked terrorists kidnapped and held hostage during the decade-long Lebanon hostage crisis.

title: Attack on USS Cole (Aden, Yemen | October 12, 2000)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the USS Cole attack. On October 12, 2000, two suicide bombers rammed a small explosives-laden boat into the USS Cole —a U.S. Navy guided missile destroyer —in the harbor at Aden, Yemen, during a routine refueling stop. The resulting explosion opened a large hole in the side of the ship, killed 17 sailors, and wounded more than 30 others. The attack was planned by members of al-Qa’ida, including now-deceased operatives Jamal Ahmed Mohammed Ali al-Badawi and Fahd Mohammed Ahmed al-Quso.

title: Kidnapping and Murder of Peter Kilburn (Beirut, Lebanon | December 3, 1984)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the kidnapping and murder of Peter Kilburn. Kilburn was a librarian at the American University of Beirut. On December 3, 1984, he was reported missing. Sixteen months later, his body was found along with those of two other captives. The victims had been shot and then dumped in the mountains east of Beirut. Kilburn was among the 100 victims, mostly Westerners, whom Hizballah and Hizballah-linked terrorists kidnapped and held hostage during the decade-long Lebanon hostage crisis.

title: Bombing of Khobar Towers (Dhahran, Saudi Arabia | June 25, 1996)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the 1996 bombing of Khobar Towers near Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. On June 25, 1996, members of Saudi Hizballah detonated a tanker truck containing plastic explosives in the parking lot of Khobar Towers, a residential complex used to house U.S. military personnel. The blast all but destroyed the nearest building, killed 19 U.S. service members and one Saudi citizen, and wounded hundreds of individuals from various nations.

title: Bombing of U.S. Embassies (Kenya and Tanzania | August 7, 1998)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the 1998 U.S. Embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania. On August 7, 1998, members of the terrorist group al-Qa’ida (AQ) simultaneously bombed the U.S. Embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam. The attacks killed 224 people, injured more than 5,000 others, and resulted in severe damage to the embassy buildings and the destruction of nearby structures.

title: Letter Bomb Incidents (U.S./U.K. | December 1996 to January 1997)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the Letter Bomb Incidents. Between December 1996 and January 1997, 16 letter bombs disguised as holiday greeting cards were delivered through the mail to recipients in the United States and the United Kingdom.

title: Consulate Murders (Karachi, Pakistan | March 8, 1995)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the 1995 murders of two U.S. Consulate General employees in Karachi, Pakistan. On March 8, 1995, a white van was carrying U.S. Consulate employees to work when a yellow taxi swerved in front of it at a busy intersection, forcing it to stop. Another car then prevented the van from moving. Masked terrorists armed with automatic rifles opened fire on the van, killing two of the consulate employees and wounding another.

title: Murders of John Granville and Abdelrahman Abbas Rahama (Khartoum, Sudan | January 1, 2008)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the murders of U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) employees John Granville and Abdelrahman Abbas Rahama. On January 1, 2008, Granville and Rahama were heading home after a New Year’s Eve party in Khartoum when they were shot and killed. Two groups separately claimed responsibility for the murders: the now-defunct al-Qa’ida in the Land of the Two Niles (AQTN) and Ansar al-Tawhid (Supporters of Monotheism).

title: Bombings of Residential Compounds (Riyadh, Saudi Arabia | May 12, 2003)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the 2003 residential compound bombings in the Saudi capital. On May 12, 2003, at least 15 assailants attacked three residential compounds in suburban Riyadh. After breaching manned security barriers, the attackers detonated car bombs in the compounds, killing 35 people, including nine Americans, and injuring nearly 200 others. The targeted facilities employed and housed a large number of Westerners, specifically U.S. and British citizens. Al-Qa’ida organized and coordinated the attack.

title: Attack on U.S. Embassy (Athens, Greece | January 12, 2007)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $1 million for information on the January 12, 2007 rocket-propelled grenade attack on the U.S. Embassy in Athens, Greece. The group claiming responsibility, Revolutionary Struggle, is believed to be an offshoot of the Greek terrorist group 17 November.

title: Bombing of American Diplomatic Convoy (Beit Hanoun, Gaza Strip | October 15, 2003)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the 2003 bombing of a U.S. diplomatic convoy in Beit Hanoun in the Gaza Strip. On October 15, 2003, a vehicle carrying four U.S. security personnel was attacked by a vehicle-borne improvised explosive device, which killed three of the individuals and seriously injured the fourth. The victims were providing security to representatives from the Office of the U.S. Middle East Envoy who were en route to Gaza to interview Palestinian student applicants for a Fulbright scholarship.

title: Murder and Kidnapping of American Citizens (Caqueta, Colombia | February 2003)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the 2003 kidnapping and murder of U.S. citizens in Colombia. On February 13, 2003, a U. S. government plane on a counter-drug mission crash landed in Caqueta, Colombia. Members of the left-wing rebel group in Colombia known as the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) killed U.S. citizen Thomas Janis and Colombian Sergeant Luis Alcides Cruz. The rebels also took hostage three other U.S. citizens who had been aboard the plane: Marc Gonsalves, Thomas Howes, and Keith Stansell.

title: Attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon (September 11, 2001)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $25 million for information on the September 11, 2001 attacks on the World Trade Center and Pentagon. Nineteen terrorists associated with al-Qa’ida (AQ) hijacked four commercial airliners en route to California, originating from three different airports in the eastern United States. The terrorists crashed two aircraft into the main towers of the World Trade Center in New York City, New York, and a third into the western side of the Pentagon in Arlington, Virginia. The fourth aircraft crashed near Shanksville, Pennsylvania, while the passengers attempted to overtake the hijackers. Overall, the attacks killed nearly 3,000 citizens of countries spanning the globe. The now-deceased leader of AQ, Usama bin Ladin, claimed responsibility for planning and implementing these attacks in a video message following the events.

title: Marine Corps Barracks Bombing (Lebanon | October 23, 1983)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the 1983 bombing of the U.S. Marine Corps Barracks in Beirut, Lebanon. On October 23, 1983, a truck bomb exploded at the housing compound of U.S. and French members of the Multinational Force in Lebanon at Beirut International Airport. The Multinational Force was in Lebanon as part of an international peacekeeping effort. The attack killed 241 U.S. military personnel and wounded 128. Later that day, 58 French soldiers were killed in a similar attack. Hizballah is believed to have orchestrated the attacks, acting with support and funding from Iran.

title: Attack Against U.S. Temporary Mission Facility and U.S. Annex  (Benghazi, Libya | September 11-12, 2012)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information on the attack against the U.S. Temporary Mission Facility and U.S. Annex in Benghazi, Libya. On September 11-12, 2012, four Americans — U.S. Ambassador to Libya John Christopher Stevens, Foreign Service Information Management Officer Sean Smith, and Protective Security Specialists Glen Anthony Doherty and Tyrone Snowden Woods— were killed in a terrorist attack against the U.S. Temporary Mission Facility and U.S. Annex in Benghazi. Terrorists launched a series of attacks involving arson, automatic weapons fire, rocket-propelled grenades, and mortars on the two U.S. facilities, as well as on U.S. personnel traveling between the two locations. In addition, the attacks severely wounded two other U.S. personnel, injured three Libyan contract guards, and resulted in the destruction and abandonment of both facilities.

title: 2017 Niger Ambush (Tongo Tongo, Niger | October 4, 2017)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the 2017 Niger Attack.

title: Murder of Joel Wesley Shrum (Taizz, Yemen | March 18, 2012)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the murder of U.S. citizen Joel Shrum. On March 18, 2012, Shrum, age 29, was shot and killed on his way to work in Taizz, Yemen by a gunman riding on the back of a motorcycle that had pulled up alongside his vehicle. A few days after the attack, the terrorist organization al-Qa’ida in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) claimed responsibility for the murder.

title: Lebanon Kidnappings and Murders (Lebanon | 1982-1992)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the kidnappings and murders of Americans in Lebanon from 1982 to 1992. During this period, Hizballah and Hizballah-linked terrorists kidnapped and held hostage nearly 100 foreign nationals, mostly Westerners. Among the kidnapping victims, Americans William Buckley, Peter Kilburn, and William Higgins were tortured and killed.

title: Kidnapping and Murder of Daniel Pearl (Karachi, Pakistan | January 23, 2002)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the kidnapping and murder of Daniel Pearl. Pearl, the South Asia Bureau Chief for the Wall Street Journal, was kidnapped in Karachi, Pakistan, on January 23, 2002. In February 2002, a video was posted on the internet depicting his murder. Pearl’s remains were found in May 2002 and returned to the United States.

title: Bombing of Pakistani Civilians (Karachi, Pakistan | June 14, 2002)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the June 14, 2002 car bombing outside the U.S. Consulate General in Karachi, Pakistan. The explosion killed 12 Pakistani civilians and injured 40 others.

title: 2008 Mumbai Attacks (Mumbai, India | November 26-29, 2008)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the 2008 Mumbai attacks. Beginning November 26, 2008, and continuing through November 29, 2008, 10 individuals trained by Lashkar-e Tayyiba (LeT), a U.S.-designated Foreign Terrorist Organization, carried out a series of coordinated terrorist attacks against multiple targets in Mumbai, India, killing 166 people. Six Americans were killed during the three-day siege: Ben Zion Chroman, Gavriel Holtzberg, Sandeep Jeswani, Alan Scherr, Naomi Scherr, and Aryeh Leibish Teitelbaum. Key members of this heinous plot remain at large, and the investigation remains ongoing.

title: Hebrew University Bombing (Jerusalem | July 31, 2002)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the July 31, 2002 bombing of Hebrew University in Jerusalem. Nine people, including five Americans, were killed and 85 were injured when a bomb exploded in Hebrew University’s cafeteria. The attackers acted on orders from the leaders of the terrorist group Hamas.

title: Planned or Past Attacks Against U.S. Diplomatic Missions Worldwide
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $3 million for information that leads to the prevention or favorable resolution of an act of terrorism against any U.S. persons or property associated with a U.S. diplomatic mission. Anyone who reports actionable information about planned or past attacks against U.S. diplomatic missions may be eligible for this reward. U.S. diplomatic missions include embassies, consular offices, embassy annexes, and other representative offices worldwide.

title: Kidnapping of Kevin Scott Sutay (El Retorno, Colombia | June 2013)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $3 million for information on the kidnapping of Kevin Scott Sutay. In June 2013, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) kidnapped Sutay, a former U.S. military service member, near the municipality of El Retorno, Colombia. Sutay had been trekking as a tourist through several Central and South American countries.

title: Violence in Opposition to the Middle East Peace Negotiations (1993 to Present)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on attacks staged in Gaza, the West Bank, and Israel to disrupt peace negotiations associated with the Oslo Accords. Since the signing of the Oslo Accords in September 1993, terrorist groups and individuals opposed to a negotiated peace agreement have staged attacks in the region to disrupt negotiations and apply pressure on associated parties engaged in dialogue.

title: Pan Am Flight 103 Bombing (Lockerbie, Scotland | December 21, 1988)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the Pan Am Flight 103 bombing. On December 21, 1988, Pan Am Flight 103, a Boeing 747 traveling from London Heathrow Airport to John F. Kennedy Airport in New York, was destroyed in-flight over Lockerbie, Scotland when an improvised explosive device, concealed in the luggage, detonated. The explosion killed all 259 passengers and crew aboard, including 190 Americans, as well as 11 residents on the ground. The attack, planned and executed by Libyan intelligence operatives, was the largest terrorist attack on Americans prior to September 11, 2001. It remains the deadliest terrorist attack in the history of the United Kingdom.

title: USO Club Bombing (Naples, Italy | April 14, 1988)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the USO Club bombing in Naples, Italy. On April 14, 1988, a car bomb exploded in front of the site, killing five people, including a U.S. servicewoman, and injuring 15 others, including four U.S. servicemen.

title: World Trade Center Bombing (New York City | February 26, 1993)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the 1993 World Trade Center bombing in New York City. On February 26, 1993, terrorists detonated a 1,500-pound truck bomb in the parking garage beneath the World Trade Center. The blast killed six people, wounded more than 1,000 others, and caused hundreds of millions of dollars in damages.

title: TWA Flight 840 Bombing (Greece | April 2, 1986)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the bombing of TWA Flight 840. On April 2, 1986, a bomb exploded on TWA Flight 840 as it traveled from Rome, Italy, to Athens, Greece. The explosion killed four U.S. citizens –including a 9-month-old infant, as well as her mother and grandmother –who were ejected from the aircraft. Five other passengers were injured. In a statement issued from Beirut, the Arab Revolutionary Cells claimed responsibility for the attack.

title: Pan Am Flight 73 Hijacking (Karachi, Pakistan | September 5, 1986)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the hijacking of Pan Am Flight 73. On September 5, 1986, suspected members of the Abu Nidal Organization terrorist group hijacked Pan Am Flight 73 while it was on the ground in Karachi, Pakistan, with 379 on board. After holding the passengers and crew hostage for nearly 16 hours, the hijackers began shooting indiscriminately. Twenty people, including two Americans, were killed and more than 100 were injured.

title: TWA Flight 847 Hijacking (Beirut, Lebanon | June 14, 1985)
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on the 1985 hijacking of TWA Flight 847. On June 14, 1985, terrorists hijacked TWA Flight 847 during a flight from Athens to Rome. Over 17 days, the plane was forced to crisscross the Mediterranean with 153 passengers and crew members, from Beirut to Algiers and back again, landing in Beirut three times. During the first stop in Beirut, the hijackers severely beat, and then shot and killed, U.S. Navy diver Robert Stethem.

title: Junzō Okudaira
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on Junzō Okudaira for the April 14, 1988 USO Club bombing in Naples, Italy. The blast killed five people, including a U.S. servicewoman, and wounded 15 others, including four U.S. servicemen. Okudaira, a member of the Japanese Red Army terrorist group, was indicted in the United States on April 9, 1993 for the USO Club attack. He is also a suspect in a June 1987 car bombing and mortar attack against the U.S. Embassy in Rome.

title: Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) Financial Network
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $15 million for information leading to the disruption of the financial mechanisms of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (

title: Jafar
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $3 million for information on Jafar, also known as Amar. Jafar is an al-Shabaab facilitator and operational planner, who has served as a deputy to Abdikadir Mohamed Abdikadir, also known as Ikrima. Jafar also serves as al-Shabaab’s chief of explosives and is responsible for attack operations in Mogadishu.

title: Hassan Afgooye
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on Hassan Afgooye, a key leader of the terrorist group al-Shabaab. Afgooye oversees a complex financial network whose activities range from fake charities and fundraising to racketeering and kidnapping in support of U.S.-designated Foreign Terrorist Organization al-Shabaab. Afgooye is considered critical to the group’s continuing operations.

title: Fuad Mohamed Khalaf
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on Fuad Mohamed Khalaf, also known as Fuad Shongale. Khalaf is a leader of al-Shabaab and has facilitated financial support for this U.S.-designated Foreign Terrorist Organization (FTO).

title: Abdullahi Yare
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $3 million for information on Abdullahi Yare, also known as Abdullahi Yarisow and Ubeyd. Yare plays a prominent religious role within al-Shabaab, a U.S.-designated Foreign Terrorist Organization. Previously, Yare served as al-Shabaab’s head of media.

title: Abu ‘Abd al-Karim al-Masri
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on Abu ‘Abd al-Karim al-Masri, also known as Karim. Al-Masri is a veteran member of al-Qa’ida (AQ) and a senior leader of Hurras al-Din (HAD), an AQ-affiliated jihadist group. In 2018, al-Masri was a member of HAD’s shura council, the group’s senior decision-making body, and served as a mediator between HAD and Hay’at Tahrir al-Sham, an AQ-linked umbrella group from which HAD had broken away.

title: Abdul Wali
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $3 million for information on Abdul Wali, also known as Omar Khalid Khorasani. Wali is the leader of Jamaat ul-Ahrar (JuA), a militant faction affiliated with Tehrik-e Taliban Pakistan (TTP), a U.S.-designated Foreign Terrorist Organization. Under Wali’s leadership, JuA has been one of the most operationally active TTP networks in Punjab Province, Pakistan and has claimed responsibility for multiple attacks throughout Pakistan.

title: Abdelkarim Hussein Mohamed al-Nasser
about: Rewards for Justice is offering a reward of up to $5 million for information on Abdelkarim Hussein Mohamed al-Nasser. Al-Nasser, an alleged leader of the Saudi Hizballah terrorist organization, is wanted for his role in the 1996 bombing of Khobar Towers near Dhahran, Saudi Arabia.
